content: let's build some doors welcome to this week's episode we're gonna build more
pieces for the miniature castle I started by cutting a thin piece of XPS
insulation foam then I used the castle walls I built earlier as a reference to
get some measurements for the doors after drawing the rough shape I cut off
the door with my knife hmmm I think it's a bit too tall so I'll
just cut away some of the material from the bottom then I made five more doors
more door so I could have six doors enough for three of the modular doors
that we are crafting there we go I cut them all out and now it's time to carve
in some textures I started by carving the arc of stones that will be around
the door so how are you doing now we can start
working on the plank door first I made three grooves the middle one is
deeper then I worked all of the cuts with a pen to get some wider grooves
which will add a lot of contrast the paint job
I made the Buddha texture by carving in
random grooves with a pen here I'm using a bowl of aluminum foil
that textures to the stone surfaces fun fact I've used this ball since my very
first video the grooves may become less defined after the aluminum foil so I'll
just make some of them again I found out it's better to make the wood textures
with a sharp pen so I sharpened mine and now I can get more defined wood red and
the next step is I'm just kidding all I need is forget it and cutting tiny
spaghetti door handles but they keep flying away this is why I have walls
I cut a total of 12 door handles of spaghetti then I glued them on the doors
with PVA glue the regular white glue
the next step will be to attach to doors with something thin but strong enough
cardstock of course I used the doors and the castle walls to get the right
measurements then I just cut out the cardstock piece and applied some glue
where the doors will be attached
as you might guess the space between the doors is equal to the width of the
castle wall if you're new here you should check out my other castle
tutorials I'll put them up somewhere once the glue has dried it's time to
paint I started by painting the non visible parts with black and the stone
surfaces were also painted with black I decided to fully paint the stone
surfaces first i dry brushed with a grey this means I only have a little paint on
the brush then I continued by dry brushing with a
lighter gray that was almost white the stone work is done the wooden doors
were painted with brown and by the way these are just cheap acrylic paints I
think I had to do about two coats of the brown because of the black paint on some
of the wood surfaces now I'm gonna use this dark wash by army painter I applied
planing of the wash so it will get into the grooves of the planks as you can see
this really brings out the wood textures it starts looking nice then I did some
dry brushing with a mixture of brown and yellow
time to paint the spaghetti door handles with gunmetal I applied the same wash on
the handles as well then painted some kind of rust with brown and yellow ooh a
bit too much paint oh but it seems to work yeah there we have it let's see how
this works cool we can easily attach the doors to our castle walls and as a bonus
the walls become steadier and won't tip as easily with the doors attached take a
look at this luckily I also made this building from equally thick foam so how
do you like this castle terrain series I'm doing it a bit different from the
monster miniatures surely if you're not for I shall make more monster miniatures
the doors look a bit small compared to this miniature it's because I use a
different scale in my games 1 centimeter equals 1 meter consistent and nice
alright here we have some decent photos of the doors do subscribe and like this
video and huge thanks to my new patrons miniature misfits and Christopher
Tennant perhaps one day I'll make so good videos that I can find you on this
list thanks and good bye
